facts.text: This is an assessee's appeal with special leave of the Supreme Court against a judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh on a reference under section 82(1) of the Hyderabad Income-tax Act corresponding to section 66(1) of the Indian Act.

anchor.surface_text: Hidayatullah, J. This is an assessees appeal, with the special leave of this companyrt, against a judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh on a reference under section 82 1  of the Hyderabad Income-tax Act, company

facts.text: The Tribunal referred four questions of law arising out of its order to the High Court, but the court is concerned only with questions Nos. 2 and 3.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal referred four questions of law arising out of order but we are companycerned only with questions Nos. 2 and 3 to be mentioned later.

facts.text: The assessee, Raja J. Rameshwar Rao, is a jagirdar of the Wanaparthi Samasthan in the former State of Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, Raja J. Rameshwar Rao, is a jagirdar of the Wanaparthi Samasthan in the former State of Hyderabad.

facts.text: The assessee was being assessed as an individual on income from the jagir and from other sources.

anchor.surface_text: He was being assessed as an individual on income from the jagir and from other sources.

facts.text: There was a village named Madanapur in the assessee's jagir.

anchor.surface_text: In his jagir, there was a village, Madanapur by name.

facts.text: The year of account was 1946 corresponding to 1356 Fasli and the year of assessment was 1947 corresponding to 1357 Fasli.

anchor.surface_text: In the year of account 1946  1356 Fasli  companyresponding to the year of assessment, 1947  1357 Fasli ,

facts.text: The assessee acquired the Makhta of the village Madanapur for Rs. 25,000 in the year of account.

anchor.surface_text: he acquired the Makhta of the village for Rs. 25,000.

facts.text: The assessee purchased 217 acres of land from the pattadars, paying Rs. 19,186 in the year of account out of total consideration of Rs. 25,502.

anchor.surface_text: He also purchased 217 acres land from the pattadars, paying them in the year of account Rs. 19,186 out of a total companysideration of Rs. 25,502.

facts.text: The assessee constructed a Ganj and shops on a portion of the land so acquired.

anchor.surface_text: He companystructed on portion of the land so acquired a Ganj and shops.

facts.text: The assessee laid out the rest of the land as plots and sold them for Rs. 75,820.

anchor.surface_text: The rest of the land he laid out as plots, which he sold for Rs. 75,820.

facts.text: In computing the assessee's assessable income, Rs. 75,820 was added as receipt from business.

anchor.surface_text: In companyputing his assessable income, Rs. 75,820 were added as receipt from business.

facts.text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Officer and the Tribunal but without success.

anchor.surface_text: He appealed to the Appellate Officer and the Tribunal, but without success.

facts.text: The assessee claimed that Rs. 75,820 could not be included in his assessable income and that expenses of Rs. 70,686 should be deducted under S. 14(5)(a) of the Hyderabad Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: he claimed that Rs. 75,820 companyld number be included in his assessable income and also that the expenses amounting to Rs.70,686/-  Rs. 25000 plus Rs.19,186/- plus Rs. 26,500/-  should be deducted as allowable expenses within the meaning of S. 14  5  a  of the Hyderabad Income-tax Act.

facts.text: The High Court held that the first question was one of fact with evidence to support the finding and answered it in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the first question was one of fact, and there was evidence to support the finding and answered the question in the affirmative.

facts.text: The High Court reframed the second question by adding words about without deducting sale proceeds of Rs. 75,820 and answered it against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The second question was reframed by the High Court by adding the words without deducting therefrom the sale proceeds of the plots sold by him amounting to Rs. 75,820 at the end of the question framed by the Tribunal. This question, the High Court answered against the assessee.

facts.text: The Supreme Court is concerned only with the first question in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, we are only companycerned with the first question, because it that question be answered in the affirmative, as did the High Court, the second question would number arise.

facts.text: The assessee contended that whether there was business and profit was a mixed question of law and fact.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended that whether there was a business and profit from it was number a question of pure fact but a mixed question of law and fact, and that the High Court was in error in treating it as a question of fact.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that there was evidence to support the finding that Rs. 75,820 was assessee's income from business.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court answered the question companyrectly.

facts.text: This was a single venture by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, this was only a single venture but even a single venture may be regarded as in the nature of trade or business.

facts.text: The expenditure has been allowed to the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In any event, the expenditure has been allowed to the assessee, and the only question is whether the income from the sale of land was properly included in his assessable income.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, this was only a single venture but even a single venture may be regarded as in the nature of trade or business. When a person acquires land with a view to selling it later after the developing it, he is carrying on an activity resulting in profit, and the activity can only be described as a business venture. Where the person goes further and divides the land into plots, develops the area to make it more attractive and sells the land number as a single unit and as he bought it but in parcels, he is dealing with land as his stock-in-trade he is carrying on business and making a profit.

concepts.interpretation: Single acquisition and sale of land after development into plots and selling as stock-in-trade constitutes business activity resulting in profit

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: a business venture. Where the person goes further and divides the land into plots, develops the area to make it more attractive and sells the land num

concepts.unlisted_description: Principle that even a single venture can constitute business or trade if involving purchase, development, and resale of land for profit

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court answered the question companyrectly. No doubt, this was only a single venture but even a single venture may be regarded as in the nature of trade or business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court examined record and found evidence supports Tribunal's finding that sale proceeds constituted business income; single venture of acquiring, developing, and selling land qualifies as business

holdings.text: even a single venture may be regarded as in the nature of trade or business. When a person acquires land with a view to selling it later after the developing it, he is carrying on an activity resulting in profit, and the activity can only be described as a business venture

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, this was only a single venture but even a single venture may be regarded as in the nature of trade or business. When a person acquires land with a view to selling it later after the developing it, he is carrying on an activity resulting in profit, and the activity can only be described as a business venture. Where the person goes further and divides the land into plots, develops the area to make it more attractive and sells the land number as a single unit and as he bought it but in parcels, he is dealing with land as his stock-in-trade he is carrying on business and making a profit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of principle that deliberate purchase, subdivision, development, and resale of land for profit constitutes business activity even if isolated transaction

holdings.reasoning_summary: The referred question was precisely whether evidence supported the Tribunal's factual finding on business income, which High Court properly assessed

holdings.text: the evidence showed that the matter went beyond the provision of marketing facilities to the inhabitants of Madanapur. anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the evidence showed that the matter went beyond the provision of marketing facilities to the inhabitants of Madanapur. The acquisition of the village and vast area of land, which certainly was number all needed for a market, the development of the land, laying out of plots and their subsequent sale, go beyond what can be described as a work for public welfare.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scale of acquisition and development exceeded mere public utility; consistent with profit-oriented business venture

holdings.text: That section deals with other sources and not with the head business

anchor.surface_text: That section deals with other sources and not with the head business. We have already said that the income from the sale of lands was by way of business, and section 14 5 a cannot be called in aid to show that the sale of land was also for public welfare.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation: provision limited to 'other sources' head of income, inapplicable to business income already determined

holdings.text: the income from the sale of land was properly included in his assessable income. We have shown above that it was properly included

anchor.surface_text: In any event, the expenditure has been allowed to the assessee, and the only question is whether the income from the sale of land was properly included in his assessable income. We have shown above that it was properly included.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior holdings confirm sale proceeds as business income taxable as such; expenditure separately allowed

anchor.surface_text: The answer given by the High Court was thus companyrect.
